description: Alterations and extensions associated with the change of use from house in multiple occupation to residential use (Class C3), including erection of first floor side extension, two storey rear extension and roof extensions including rear dormer with roof terrace to facilitate loft conversion to provide two dwellinghouses (retaining PH facilities within rear ground floor of 102 Villiers Road)
decision_conditions: Development  shall  be  carried  out  in  accordance  with  the  materials  specified  on  the approved plans and on the application form unless otherwise agreed in writing by the Local Planning Authority.Reason: To ensure a satisfactory appearance on completion of the development in accordance with Policy DM10 (Design Requirements for New Developments including House Extensions) of the LDF Core Strategy Adopted April 2012.
The development hereby permitted shall begin before the expiration of three years from the date of this permission.Reason: This is required by Section 91 of the Town and Country Planning Act 1990.

No building or use hereby permitted shall be occupied or the use commenced until the cycle parking provision shown on the approved plans has been completed, and thereafter, be kept free of obstruction and available for the parking of cycles only.Reason: To ensure the provision of adequate cycling facilities in accordance with Policy DM10 (Design Requirements for New Developments including House Extensions) of the LDF Core Strategy Adopted April 2012.

No development shall commence until a landscaping scheme including where applicable the retention of the existing trees shall have been submitted to and approved in writing by the Local Planning Authority.  The approved scheme shall be implemented within the first planting season following completion of the development and the tree planting and landscaping shall thereafter be maintained for five years to the satisfaction of the Local Planning Authority.  Any trees or shrubs which die during this period shall be replaced in the first available planting season, and the area shown to be landscaped shall be permanently retained for that purpose only.  Reason: In the interests of visual amenity and also that the Local Planning Authority shall be satisfied as to the details of the development in accordance with Policy DM10 (Design Requirements for New Developments including House Extensions) of the LDF Core Strategy Adopted April 2012.

Evidence must be submitted to the Council confirming that the development hereby permitted has achieved no less than the C02 reductions (ENE1), internal water usage (WAT1) standards equivalent to Code for Sustainable Homes Level 4.  Evidence requirements are detailed in the "Schedule of Evidence Required for Post Construction Stage from ENE1 and WAT1 of the Code for Sustainable Homes Guide.  Evidence to demonstrate a 19% reduction compared to 2013 Part L regulations and internal water usage rates of 105L/day.Reason: In the interests of Sustainability and Energy Conservation in accordance with Policies 5.2 (Minimising Carbon Dioxide Emissions) and 5.3 (Sustainable Design & Construction) of the London Plan (July 2011) and Policy DM1 (Sustainable Design and Construction Standards) of the LDF Core Strategy Adopted April 2012.

No building or use hereby permitted shall be occupied or the use commenced until the refuse store, and area/facilities allocated for storing of recyclable materials, as shown on approved plan have been completed in accordance with the approved plans. The developer and/or their successors in title shall take all reasonable steps to ensure that all refuse and recyclable materials associated with the development shall either be stored within this dedicated store/area as shown on the approved plans, or internally within the building(s) that form part of the application site, and that no refuse or recycling material shall be stored or placed for collection on the public highway or pavement, except on the day of collection.Reason: To ensure the provision of refuse facilities to the satisfaction of the Council in accordance with Policy DM10 (Design Requirements for New Developments including House Extensions) of the LDF Core Strategy Adopted April 2012.

No development shall take place including any works of demolition until a construction logistics plan has been submitted to and been approved in writing by the Local Planning Authority.  The approved plan/statement shall be adhered to throughout the construction period. The statement shall provide for:(a) Provision for loading/unloading materials.(b) Storage of plant, materials and operatives vehicles.(c) Temporary site access.(d) Signing system for works traffic.(e) Measures for the laying of dust, suppression of noise and abatement of other nuisance arising from development works.(f) Location of all ancillary site buildings.(g) Measures to protect any tree, shrubbery and other landscape features to be retained on the site during the course of development.(h) Means of enclosure of the site.(i) Wheel washing equipment.(j) The parking of vehicles of the site operatives and visitors(k) The erection and maintenance of security hoarding.Reason:  These details are required prior to commencement of development because the relevant works would take place at the beginning of the construction phase,  and in order to safeguard the amenities of the surrounding residential occupiers and to safeguard highway safety and the free flow of traffic in accordance with Policy DM10 (Design Requirements for New Developments including House Extensions) of the LDF Core Strategy Adopted April 2012.

No development shall take place until a detailed acoustic report on the existing noise climate at the development site has been submitted to and been approved in writing by the Local Planning Authority. The acoustic report should demonstrate how noise generated from the adjacent public house internally (music and customer voices) and externally (customer voices) will be sufficiently controlled to prevent adverse impact upon the occupiers of the proposed development at ground and first floor level at 102 Villiers Road. The report shall also include a survey and detailed design to identify what measures, if any, are required to prevent flanking sound transmission through the ceiling structure when supporting joists are tied into the existing party wall.The noise assessment shall be carried out by a suitably qualified acoustic consultant/engineer and shall take into account the provisions of BS 8233: 2014 Guidance on sound insulation and noise reduction for buildings.Reason:   These details are required prior to commencement of development because the details would affect subsequent design of other elements of the scheme and must be agreed at the outset and in the interests of the amenities of future occupiers of the accommodation hereby approved in accordance with Policy DM10 of the of the LDF Core Strategy Adopted April 2012.

No development shall take place until a detailed scheme of noise insulation measures for  the proposed development at ground and first floor level at 102 Villiers Road has been submitted to and been approved in writing by the Local Planning Authority. The scheme of noise insulation measures shall be prepared by a suitably qualified consultant/engineer and shall take into account the provisions of BS 8233: 2014 Guidance on sound insulation and noise reduction for buildings. The approved scheme shall be implemented prior to the commencement of the use and be permanently retained thereafter.Reason:   These details are required prior to commencement of development because the details would affect subsequent design of other elements of the scheme and must be agreed at the outset and in the interests of the amenities of future occupiers of the accommodation hereby approved in accordance with Policy DM10 of the of the LDF Core Strategy Adopted April 2012.

Except for the roof terrace shown on the approved drawing, the roof of the extension hereby permitted shall not be converted or used as a balcony or a sitting out area, and no access shall be gained except for maintenance purposes.Reason: To protect the amenities and privacy of the adjoining residential properties in accordance with Policy DM10 (Design Requirements for New Developments including House Extensions) of the LDF Core Strategy Adopted April 2012.

Unless otherwise agreed in writing by the Local Planning Authority, the roof terrace hereby approved shall not be used for amenity purposes until a privacy screen has been affixed around the entirety of the terrace to a height of 1.7m as measured from the floor level of the balcony/terrace. Aside from essential fixings, the screen(s) shall be constructed entirely of, and retained in, obscured glazing to a minimum of level 3 on the standard scale. Any film used to achieve the requisite obscurity level shall be non-perishable and tamper-proof, and must be replaced in the event that it ceases to result in obscurity to level 3.Reason: To protect the amenities and privacy of the occupiers of the adjoining residential properties in accordance with Policy DM10 (Design Requirements for New Developments including House Extensions) of the LDF Core Strategy Adopted April 2012.

Application SiteThe application site is occupied by a two storey detached dwelling, located on the northern side of Ullswater Crescent.The site is also located within the Kingston Hill/Coombe Hill Strategic Area of Special Character.ProposalThe application seeks permission for raising roof height, erection of rear dormer roof extension and installation of 2 nos front rooflights to facilitate loft conversion. Alteration of existing roof.Planning History22/00921/HOU - Erection of rear dormer roof extension and installation of 2 nos front rooflights to facilitate loft conversion. Alteration to roof design. Refused for the following reason:'The proposed raising of the roof height and alteration to the roof design would appear  as an inappropriate and dominant addition to the host property, resulting in an incongruous appearance within the streetscene. This would have an unacceptable impact on the character and appearance of the immediate surrounding area and would result in harm to the significance of the Kingston Hill/Coombe Hill Strategic Area of Special Character. The proposed development would therefore conflict with Paragraph 203 of the NPPF, 2021, Policy Paragraph HC1 of the London Plan 2021 and Policies CS8, DM10 and DM12 of the Council's Core Strategy 2012.'The current scheme has reduced the raising of the roof height from 400mm to 250mm. Officers note that the supporting information states a raise in roof height of 200mm but the plans show 250mm.Consultation10 properties were notified of the proposal. No representations were received.AssessmentThe main issues in the assessment of the application are:- The impact of the development on the character and appearance of the area; - The impact of the development on heritage assets; and,- The impact of the development on the amenities of neighbouring occupiers.Character and AppearancePolicy D3 of the London Plan 2021 states that development proposals should enhance local context by delivering buildings and spaces that positively respond to local distinctiveness through their layout, orientation, scale, appearance and shape, with due regard to existing and emerging street hierarchy, building types, forms and proportions.Policies CS8 and DM10 of the Council's Core Strategy 2012 and the guidance in the Council's Residential Design Guide SPD 2013 require proposals to be of a high quality design that respects the character and appearance of the original building and the prevailing character of the surrounding area. Whilst the proposed rear dormer itself is of an acceptable scale and external design, the proposed raise in roof height of 250mm, would alter the overall roof profile when viewed from the streetscene and result in one that would not be compatible with surrounding properties. With the exception of No.77 Ullswater Crescent, which is a result of a permission that predates the current Core Strategy and Residential Design SPD policy guidance, the roof profiles of properties with Ullswater Crescent appear mostly intact and consistent in their appearance. Furthermore, a recent permission for a rear dormer at No.63 (2200777/HOU) ensures the roof profile to the street scene remains intact. Officers acknowledge the proposal reduces the roof height proposed in the earlier application however the roof profile when viewed from the street scene would still be altered.Having regard to the above, officers therefore consider that the proposed development would have an unacceptable impact on the character and appearance of the area.Heritage AssetsParagraphs 199 to 208 of the NPPF 2021 set out the method for assessing the impact of development proposals on heritage assets. Policy HC1 of the London Plan 2021 and Policies CS8 and DM12 of the Council's Core Strategy 2012 echo these requirements.Paragraph 203 states that the effect of an application on the significance of a non-designated heritage asset should be taken into account in determining any application. In weighing applications that directly or indirectly affect non-designated heritage assets, a balanced judgement is required, having regard to the scale of any harm or loss and the significance of the heritage asset.The application site neither contains, nor forms part of any designated heritage assets. However, it does fall within the Kingston Hill/Coombe Hill Strategic Area of Special Character (SASC), which is a non-designated heritage asset. The significance of the Kingston Hill/Coombe Hill SASC relates to an area of fine houses and lodges set in a landscape of exceptional quality, which began as a series of small estates in the late 18th century.The proposed raise and resultant change in the roof profile is not considered by officers to respect the prevailing character and appearance of properties in the immediate vicinity, and in particular the consistency in the roof profile and established character of properties as they appear to the street.Having regard to the above officers consider the proposal would result in harm to the Kingston Hill/Coombe Hill SASC. Neighbouring AmenitiesPolicy D3 of the London Plan 2021 states that development proposals should deliver appropriate outlook, privacy and amenity, and should help prevent or mitigate the impacts of noise and poor air quality.Policy DM10 of the Council's Core Strategy also seeks to safeguard the amenities of neighbouring occupiers. To this end, it states that developments should have regard to the amenities of occupants and neighbours, including in terms of privacy, outlook, sunlight/daylight, avoidance of visual intrusion and noise and disturbance.Given the siting and scale of the proposed development, it is not considered this part of the proposal would have any adverse impact on the amenities of the neighbouring properties at Nos.69 or 73 Ullswater Crescent.Fire SafetyLondon Plan Policy D12(A) requires all development proposals to achieve the highest standards of fire safety, embedding these at the earliest possible stage.Officer comment: The applicant has submitted a Fire Safety Strategy and Plans which demonstrate the provision of a suitable evacuation assembly point and fire safety measures within the building to comply with the London Plan. Officers see no reason why a development of the type sought could not comply with the rest of the provisions of Policy D12(A), the details of which could be secured through conditions. For these reasons, officers conclude that the proposal would not conflict with Policy D12 of the London Plan.In conclusion, the proposed development would be contrary to the National Planning Policy Framework (2021), the National Planning Practice Guidance, the London Plan (2021), Policies of the Core Strategy (2012) and the Residential Design SPD (2013).

SiteThe application site is a two-storey semi-detached dwellinghouse located on 86 Willoughby Road. The site is located within a Controlled Parking Zone. Planning History22/01219/CPU - Erection of rear dormer roof extension with installation of 2no front rooflights to facilitate loft conversion. Associated changes to fenestration. Refuse on 06 Jun 2022.Consultations9 neighbouring properties have been notified of the proposals and no representations were received.ConsiderationThe key areas of assessment are: The impact of the development on character and appearance. The impact of the development on the amenities of existing and future occupants of land and buildings.The impact of the development on fire safety. When read together Policies CS8 and DM10 of the Royal Borough of Kingston upon Thames Local Development Framework Core Strategy (CS)(2012) and the guidance in the Royal Borough of Kingston upon Thames Residential Design Guide SPD (2013) require proposals to be of a high quality design that respects the character and appearance of the original building and the prevailing character of the surrounding area.Officers Comments: The application proposes the construction of an L-shaped dormer extension to the rear, as well as the installation of 2 no. rooflights to the front roofslope. Finally the application proposes the installation of three obscure glazed windows on the side elevation of the dwellinghouse. Whilst the proposed flat roof L-shaped dormer extension would not strictly conform to the recommendations of the Residential Design SPD, Officers note that the proposed development would not be uncharacteristic of this area of Willoughby Road. As such, it is considered that there would be no adverse impact on the character and appearance of the dwellinghouse or area as a result of the proposed development. Policy DM10 of the Royal Borough of Kingston upon Thames Local Development Framework Core Strategy (CS)(2012) and the guidance in the Royal Borough of Kingston upon Thames Residential Design Guide SPD (2013) requires proposal to have regard to the amenities of the future occupants of the development as well as those of the existing occupants of neighbouring land and buildings, including in terms of privacy, outlook, sunlight/daylight, avoidance of visual intrusion and noise and disturbance.Officers Comments: It is considered that the proposed development would not adversely affect the amenities of the occupiers of neighbouring properties by reason of overbearing appearance, loss of light or loss of privacy. Nevertheless, in the interest of the privacy of the neighbouring property at No. 88 Willoughby Road, Officers consider it appropriate to attach a condition to the permission in the event of an approval to ensure that the proposed new windows on the side elevation of the property are installed as obscure glazed and retained as such. London Plan Policy D12(A) requires all development proposals to achieve the highest standards of fire safety, embedding these at the earliest possible stage.Officer comment: The applicant has not submitted a Fire Safety Strategy, however, the plans include the provision of a suitably positioned outside space for fire appliances/ an evacuation assembly point and officers see no reason why a development of the type sought could not comply with the rest of the provisions of Policy D12(A), the details of which could be secured through conditions. For these reasons, officers conclude that the proposal would not conflict with Policy D12 of the London Plan.In conclusion, the proposed development would be in general accordance with the National Planning Policy Framework (2021), the National Planning Practice Guidance, the London Plan (2021), Policies of the Core Strategy (2012) and the Residential Design SPD (2013).

SiteThe application site consists of a semi-detached two storey single dwellinghouse The surrounding area is predominately residential in character. The site is located within an Area of archaeological significance  and within Flood Zone 2. ProposalErection of single-storey rear/side extension, new side porch and first floor rear extension.6 neighbouring properties have been notified of the proposals.  2 representations have been received objecting to the proposal on the following grounds:Absence of first floor extensions in the vicinity of the application property;Loss of sunlight/daylight and outlook to neighbouring properties;Other non material planning considerations that are building regulations related include:Structural integrity of property and its foundations;Party wall matters including any encroachments or damage to boundary walls.The key areas of assessment are:- The design of the proposed development; and;- The impact of the development on the amenities of existing and future occupants of land and buildings.When read together Policies CS8 and DM10 of the Royal Borough of Kingston upon Thames Local Development Framework Core Strategy (CS)(2012) and the guidance in the Royal Borough of Kingston upon Thames Residential Design Guide SPD (2013) require proposals to be of a high quality design that respects the character and appearance of the original building and the prevailing character of the surrounding area. Officer Comment: The proposed single storey rear extension would match the depth of the existing extension at No.61 Clayton Road and is og an acceptable scale and design.The proposed first floor rear extension is modest in scale and depth, with a roof form to match the host dwelling and also finished externally to match the host dwelling. Whilst no other first floor extensions are evident in the immediate vicinity of the site given the above no objection is raised to this part of the proposal.No objection is raised to the proposed side porch which is considered to be acceptable in terms of scale, roof form, siting and design.It is considered that there would be no adverse impacts on the character or appearance of the area as a result of the proposed development.Policy DM10 of the Royal Borough of Kingston upon Thames Local Development Framework Core Strategy (CS)(2012) and the guidance in the Royal Borough of Kingston upon Thames Residential Design Guide SPD (2013) requires proposal to have regard to the amenities of the future occupants of the development as well as those of the existing occupants of neighbouring land and buildings, including in terms of privacy, outlook, sunlight/daylight, avoidance of visual intrusion and noise and disturbance.Officer Comment:  It has been demonstrated that the proposal would not unduly impact any neighbouring property at No.61 Clayton Road  in terms of loss of sunlight/daylight as a result of the proposed first floor extension. Given the scale and siting of the proposed extensions it is not considered there would be an unacceptable impact on the amenities of No.65 Clayton Road. Flood RiskPolicy SI12 of the London Plan 2021 and policy DM4 of the Council's Core strategy 2012 require development proposals to accord with the flood risk policies set out in the NPPF.Officer Comment: As set out above, the application site falls within Flood Risk Zone 2 (medium probability). Consequently the Flood Risk Assessment: Standing Advice issued by the Environment Agency and DEFRA, 2012 must be applied. For minor extensions such as this it is essential that the proposed floor level is no lower than existing in order to mitigate future flood risk impacts. A flood risk assessment has been submitted with the proposal stating the proposed floor levels will be set no lower than existing, and other flood mitigation measures to be undertaken in line with the EA standing advice. As such, officers are satisfied the proposal would not have an adverse impact on flooding.Fire safetyLondon Plan Policy D12(A) requires all development proposals to achieve the highest standards of fire safety, embedding these at the earliest possible stage.Officer comment: The applicant has not submitted a Fire Safety Strategy to demonstrate the provision of a suitable evacuation assembly point and fire safety measures within the building to comply with the London Plan. However, officers see no reason why a development of the type sought could not comply with the provisions of Policy D12(A), the details of which could be secured through conditions. For these reasons, officers conclude that the proposal would not conflict with Policy D12 of the London Plan.In conclusion, the proposed development would be contrary to National Planning Policy Framework (2019), the National Planning Practice Guidance, the London Plan (2021), Policies of the Core Strategy (2012) and the Residential Design SPD (2013).

SiteThe application site is a two-storey semi-detached dwellinghouse located on The Manor Drive. The site is not subject to any particular designations or environmental constraints.The application follows a refused application for a similar sized extension and front overhang to create sheltered area to front door ref: 22/01061/HOU. This proposal has removed the front overhang.ConsultationsEight neighbouring properties have been notified of the proposals and no representations were received.ConsiderationThe key areas of assessment are: - The design of the proposed development; - The impact of the development on the amenities of existing and future occupants of land and buildings; and - Fire SafetyDesign When read together Policies CS8 and DM10 of the Royal Borough of Kingston upon Thames Local Development Framework Core Strategy (CS)(2012) and the guidance in the Royal Borough of Kingston upon Thames Residential Design Guide SPD (2013) require proposals to be of a high quality design that respects the character and appearance of the original building and the prevailing character of the surrounding area.Officer Comments:The proposed single storey rear extension is considered to be acceptable in terms of scale, form, bulk, height, massing, spacing and design. It is considered that there would be no adverse impacts on the character or appearance of the area as a result of the proposed development. Having regard to the above, officers consider that the proposed development would have an acceptable impact on the character and appearance of the area.AmenityPolicy DM10 of the Royal Borough of Kingston upon Thames Local Development Framework Core Strategy (CS)(2012) and the guidance in the Royal Borough of Kingston upon Thames Residential Design Guide SPD (2013) requires proposal to have regard to the amenities of the future occupants of the development as well as those of the existing occupants of neighbouring land and buildings, including in terms of privacy, outlook, sunlight/daylight, avoidance of visual intrusion and noise and disturbance.Officer Comments: The principal properties to consider in relation to amenity are Nos. 57 & 61  Manor Drive North.   The proposed rear extension would be small in scale, given the size and orientation of the site it is considered that the proposed development would not adversely affect the amenities of the occupiers of neighbouring properties.   Given the siting of the proposed development in relation to the closest habitable windows of neighbouring properties, it is considered that the proposed development would not adversely affect the amenities of the occupiers of neighbouring properties by reason of overbearing appearance, loss of light or loss of privacy.Fire SafetyLondon Plan Policy D12(A) requires all development proposals to achieve the highest standards of fire safety, embedding these at the earliest possible stage.Officer comment: The applicant has not submitted a Fire Safety Strategy, however, the plans include the provision of a suitably positioned outside space for fire appliances/ an evacuation assembly point and officers see no reason why a development of the type sought could not comply with the rest of the provisions of Policy D12(A), the details of which could be secured through conditions. For these reasons, officers conclude that the proposal would not conflict with Policy D12 of the London Plan.In conclusion, the proposed development would be in general accordance with the National Planning Policy Framework (2021), the National Planning Practice Guidance, the London Plan (2021), Policies of the Core Strategy (2012) and the Residential Design SPD (2013)

The site comprises a semi-detached dwelling.14 neighbouring properties have been notified of the proposals and no representations have been received. The key areas of assessment are: - The design of the proposed development; - The impact of the development on the amenities of existing and future occupants of land and buildings; and, - Fire Safety Assessment.DesignWhen read together Policies CS8 and DM10 of the Royal Borough of Kingston upon Thames Local Development Framework Core Strategy (CS)(2012) and the guidance in the Royal Borough of Kingston upon Thames Residential Design Guide SPD (2013) require proposals to be of a high quality design that respects the character and appearance of the original building and the prevailing character of the surrounding area. Officer Comment: The proposed single storey rear and side extension would have a depth that is slightly over the recommendations set out in the Residential Design SPD, however it would have a modest height and as such would appear a proportionate and subordinate addition to the host property. As such, it is considered that there would be no adverse impacts on the character or appearance of the area as a result of the proposed development. While the removal of the chimney stack would unbalance the roof profiles of the pair of semi-detached properties, officers note that the chimney stack is positioned to the rear of the existing roofslope and as such has limited visibility from the streetscene. As such, officers consider that the removal of the chimney stack would not detract from the character and appearance of the original dwelling or surrounding area.AmenityPolicy DM10 of the Royal Borough of Kingston upon Thames Local Development Framework Core Strategy (CS)(2012) and the guidance in the Royal Borough of Kingston upon Thames Residential Design Guide SPD (2013) requires proposal to have regard to the amenities of the future occupants of the development as well as those of the existing occupants of neighbouring land and buildings, including in terms of privacy, outlook, sunlight/daylight, avoidance of visual intrusion and noise and disturbance. Officer Comment: Given the modest eaves height of the proposed development, officers consider that the proposed development would not adversely affect the amenities of the occupiers of neighbouring properties by reason of overbearing appearance, loss of light or loss of privacy. Fire Safety AssessmentLondon Plan Policy D12(A) requires all development proposals to achieve the highest standards of fire safety, embedding these at the earliest possible stage.Officer Comment: The applicant has not submitted a Fire Safety Strategy, however, the plans include the provision of a suitably positioned outside space for fire appliances/ an evacuation assembly point and officers see no reason why a development of the type sought could not comply with the rest of the provisions of Policy D12(A), the details of which could be secured through conditions.
